description: From Middle English crappe, also in plural: crappys, craps (“chaff; buckwheat”), from Middle French crape, from Old French crappe, crapin (“chaff”) (compare Medieval Latin crappa pl, also crapinum), from Old Dutch krappen (“to cut off, pluck off”) (whence Middle Dutch crappe, crap (“a chop, cutlet”), whence Dutch krip (“a steak”)). Related to crop.

entries.meaning: (chiefly UK, Canada, US, colloquial, mildly vulgar) Of poor quality.
examples: I drove an old crap car for ten years before buying a new one.

entries.meaning: (slang, mildly vulgar, uncountable) Something worthless or of poor quality; junk.
examples: The long-running game show went from offering good prizes to crap in no time.

entries.meaning: (slang, mildly vulgar, uncountable) Nonsense; something untrue.
examples: The college student boasted of completing a 10,000-word essay on Shakespeare, but that claim was utter crap.
I stepped in some dog crap that was on the sidewalk.

entries.meaning: (slang, mildly vulgar, countable) An act of defecation.
examples: I have to take a crap.

verbs.description: crap (third-person singular simple present craps, present participle crapping, simple past and past participle crapped)

examples: That soup tasted funny, and now I need to crap.

entries.meaning: (mildly vulgar, slang, transitive) To defecate in or on (clothing etc.).
examples: He almost crapped his pants from fright.

entries.meaning: (India, mildly vulgar, slang, transitive) To bullshit.
examples: Don't try to crap me: I know you're lying.

entries.meaning: (gambling, dice games) A losing throw of 2, 3, or 12 in craps.
